title: Quiz 1: July 2021 FQE
description: Final Qualifying Examination - July 2021. Covers database concepts, Access, Excel, and HTML basics.

questions.question: The process of finding errors and fixing them within a program is called?
questions.explanation: Debugging is the systematic process of identifying, analyzing, and removing errors (bugs) from software code. Compiling converts code, scanning reads input, and executing runs the program.
questions.hint: Think about the term used for removing 'bugs' from software.

questions.question: Which tool do you use to create a query object?
questions.explanation: In Microsoft Access, the 'Simple Query Wizard' is a specific tool used to create basic SELECT queries by selecting fields from tables.
questions.hint: It is the most basic wizard for asking questions of your data.

questions.question: Which of the following is the ascending order of data hierarchy?
questions.explanation: The data hierarchy is organized from smallest to largest: Bit (0/1) -> Byte (Character) -> Field (Data item) -> Record (Collection of fields) -> File/Table (Collection of records) -> Database.
questions.hint: Start with the smallest unit of data (0 or 1) and end with the largest collection.

questions.question: Database access levels are specified so as to define who can access what in a database. It is identified through?
questions.explanation: The User ID (Authentication) is the primary identifier used to determine a user's identity. Once identified, the system checks permissions associated with that ID.
questions.hint: This is the unique name or number given to a specific person to identify them to the system.

questions.question: A search value can be exact value or it can be?
questions.explanation: When searching in a database, you can specify an exact match or use Wildcard characters (e.g., * or ?) to represent unknown characters.
questions.hint: A special character used to substitute for any other character in a string.

questions.question: In which method we don't need to specify the field type and size while creating a new table?
questions.explanation: When creating a table by simply entering data (Datasheet View), Access attempts to automatically infer the data type and size based on the values typed.
questions.hint: This method involves typing directly into the grid without setting up the structure first.

questions.question: The size of Yes/No field is always?
questions.explanation: A Yes/No field (Boolean) requires only 1 bit of storage to represent two states (0 for No, 1 for Yes).
questions.hint: It is the smallest unit of data possible, storing only a 0 or a 1.

questions.question: Which kind of query displays its own dialog box prompting you for entering information before executing?
questions.explanation: A parameter query prompts the user for input (like a date range or specific name) using a dialog box each time the query is run.
questions.hint: It asks for a 'parameter' or criteria before running.

questions.question: Which field type can store photos?
questions.explanation: OLE (Object Linking and Embedding) Object fields are used in Microsoft Access to store complex binary data such as images, documents, and graphs.
questions.hint: This technology allows embedding objects from other applications.

questions.question: If you create a 'Student' field in 'Fees' table to store 'Student_id' of 'Student' table, then this 'Student' field in 'Fees' table is called?
questions.explanation: A Foreign Key is a field in one table that links to the Primary Key of another table, establishing a relationship between them.
questions.hint: It is a key that 'lives' in another table to point back to the source.

questions.question: The complete information about an entity in a database is called?
questions.explanation: A record (or tuple) contains all the data fields related to a single entity (e.g., all details for one specific patient).
questions.hint: It is represented as a row in a table.

questions.question: The input mask wizard does not include the ability to do which of the following?
questions.explanation: The Input Mask Wizard handles masks, placeholders, and storage of symbols. Forcing text to uppercase is typically done using the Format property (using the > symbol), not the Input Mask Wizard.
questions.hint: Changing the case of letters is a 'Format' property, not an 'Input Mask' function.

questions.question: This data type allows alphanumeric characters and special symbols?
questions.explanation: The Text (or Short Text) data type is designed to store alphanumeric characters (letters, numbers, and symbols). Memo is for long text.
questions.hint: The most common data type for names and addresses.

questions.question: Query design has two parts. The upper part shows?

options.text: Name of fields, field types and size
Tables with fields and relationships between tables

questions.explanation: In Access Query Design View, the upper pane displays the tables added to the query and the relationship lines between them. The lower pane is the design grid.
questions.hint: It shows the sources of your data and how they are connected.

questions.question: Any report, including basic report can be modified in?
questions.explanation: Reports can be modified in Design View and Layout View. Layout View allows you to visually modify the report (resize columns, move fields) while viewing live data.
questions.hint: This view lets you fix the 'layout' while seeing the data.

questions.question: Using the keyboard ________ will return a record in which the field value equals a defined text.
questions.explanation: The 'Equal' operator (or simply typing the value) is used to find records that match a defined text exactly.
questions.hint: It checks for an exact match.

questions.question: In Ms Access ‘lookup wizard’ is use to?
questions.explanation: The Lookup Wizard creates a field that allows you to choose a value from another table or from a list of values you type in.
questions.hint: It creates a drop-down list populated by data from elsewhere.

questions.question: The basic elements of a form or a report are called?
questions.explanation: Controls are the individual elements (such as text boxes, labels, buttons, check boxes) that make up the user interface of a form or report.
questions.hint: Buttons, text boxes, and labels are all examples of these.

questions.question: In Ms PowerPoint, which of the following is not a part of slide design?
questions.explanation: 'Design view' is a term used in Access or web design. PowerPoint has Design Templates, Layouts, and Color Schemes, but 'Design view' is not a standard PowerPoint view name.
questions.hint: This term is commonly used in Database or Web design, not presentation software.

questions.question: What lets you create new presentation by selecting ready-made font colour and graphic effects?
questions.explanation: A Design Template provides a consistent look and feel for a presentation by defining the background, font styles (font color/scheme), and graphic effects.
questions.hint: It is a pre-made design file that acts as a starting point.

questions.question: Which of the following is not one of PowerPoint views?
questions.explanation: Standard PowerPoint views include Normal, Slide Sorter, Reading View, and Slide Show View. 'Presentation view' is not a standard interface view name.
questions.hint: The view used during the actual speech is called Slide Show or Presenter View, but 'Presentation view' isn't standard.

questions.question: A function inside another function is called?
questions.explanation: When a function is used as an argument within another function (e.g., =IF(AND(A1>0...), ...)), it is called a nested function.
questions.hint: Like Russian dolls, one fits inside the other.

questions.question: Which function will you use to enter current time in a worksheet cell?
questions.explanation: =NOW() returns the current date and time. =TODAY() returns only the date. =TIME() requires specific hour/minute/second arguments.
questions.hint: This function gives you the date and time right 'now'.

questions.question: Long text can be broken down into many lines within a cell. You can do this through?
questions.explanation: The 'Wrap Text' feature in Excel allows long text to wrap onto multiple lines within a single cell, increasing the row height to fit the content.
questions.hint: This feature prevents text from spilling over into the next cell by making it taller.

questions.question: Getting data from a cell located in a different sheet is called?
questions.explanation: This is specifically known as cell referencing (or 3D referencing). For example, Sheet2!A1 references cell A1 in Sheet2.
questions.hint: You are making a 'reference' to another location.

questions.question: Multiple calculations can be made in a single formula using?
questions.explanation: An Array Formula performs multiple calculations on one or more items in an array and returns either a single result or multiple results.
questions.hint: It deals with a collection (array) of data points at once.

questions.question: The correct sequence of HTML tags for starting a web page is?
questions.explanation: The standard structure is: HTML (root) -> Head (meta info) -> Title (inside Head) -> Body (visible content).
questions.hint: The HTML tag wraps everything. The Head comes before the Body.

questions.question: Which of the following tags is used to insert the largest heading in HTML?
questions.explanation: The <h1> tag defines the most important (largest) heading. <h6> defines the least important (smallest) heading.
questions.hint: H1 is the first and biggest heading.

questions.question: How to create an unordered list (a list with the list items in bullets) in HTML?
questions.explanation: The <ul> tag defines an Unordered List (bullet points). <ol> defines an Ordered List (numbers).
questions.hint: U.L. stands for Unordered List.

questions.question: Which character is used to represent the closing of a tag in HTML?
questions.explanation:
A forward slash / is used in the closing tag. For example: Opening tag

, Closing tag

.
questions.hint: It's the forward slash.
